user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetID:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetID(void)
{
    int32 IdBuf;

    /* always delegate to low-level API */
    if (OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(&IdBuf) != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* return a hardcoded value on failure */
        return -1;
    }

    return IdBuf;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_NetworkGetID:
int32 OS_NetworkGetID_Impl(int32 *IdBuf)
{
    /* gethostid() has no failure modes */
    *IdBuf = gethostid();
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
void *UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;
    void *               ReturnPtr;

    ReturnPtr = NULL;
    StubPtr   = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);

    if (StubPtr == NULL)
    {
        /* This shouldn't happen, it means the stub tried to use a
         * return buffer that does not exist.
         *
         * It is most likely caused by a mismatch/incompatibility between
         * stub and handler.  Aborting now is better than segfaulting later,
         * as the errored call should still be on the stack trace
         */
        UtAssert_Abort("Return buffer invalid");
    }
    else
    {
        ReturnPtr = StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr;

        /*
         * Sanity check on the size and type name.
         *
         * In a generated stub these should always match, but if any patches
         * were done or if a hand-written stub is used, mistakes could be made.
         */
        if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position != ReturnSize || strcmp(TypeName, StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr) != 0)
        {
            UtAssert_Failed("Return value mismatch, expected %s(%lu) got %s(%lu)", TypeName, (unsigned long)ReturnSize,
                            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr, (unsigned long)StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position);
        }
    }

    return ReturnPtr;
}
...
void UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler)
{
    /* Check if the test case registered a hook, and use the default if not */
    if (UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER) == NULL && DefaultHandler != NULL)
    {
        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);
}
...
void UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, size_t ReturnSize, const char *TypeName)
{
    UT_StubTableEntry_t *StubPtr;

    if (ReturnSize > 0)
    {
        /* Check for existing buffer and re-use if same size (should be!) */
        StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER);
        if (StubPtr != NULL && StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize != ReturnSize)
        {
            UT_ClearStubEntry(StubPtr);
            StubPtr = NULL;
        }

        if (StubPtr == NULL)
        {
            StubPtr = UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_UNUSED);
            if (StubPtr == NULL)
            {
                UtAssert_Abort("Cannot set return buffer - UT_MAX_FUNC_STUBS too low?");
            }
            else
            {
                StubPtr->FuncKey           = FuncKey;
                StubPtr->EntryType         = UT_ENTRYTYPE_RETURN_BUFFER;
                StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr = malloc(ReturnSize);
                if (StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr == NULL)
                {
                    UtAssert_Abort("Cannot allocate data buffer - malloc() failed!");
                }
                else
                {
                    memset(StubPtr->Data.Buff.BasePtr, 0, ReturnSize);
                    StubPtr->ModeFlags |= UT_MODEFLAG_ALLOC_BUF;
                }

                StubPtr->Data.Buff.TotalSize = ReturnSize;
            }
        }

        if (StubPtr != NULL)
        {
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.Position       = 0;
            StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr = TypeName;
        }
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Included fragments are all places in the provided code where pointer-to-object types are declared/assigned without const qualification and thus could merit examination under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 (i.e. where a pointer might reasonably point to a const-qualified type). Other code fragments were not selected for the following reasons:

- OS_NetworkGetID (the top-level wrapper) does not declare any pointer parameters or pointer-to-object types; it only passes the address of a local int32 to the implementation, so there is no missing const qualification to check in that function itself.

- Function parameters that are already const-qualified (e.g. const char *TypeName, const char *FunctionName) were not flagged because they already follow the rule.

- Buffer pointers that are intentionally modifiable (e.g. BasePtr returned from malloc and later used with memset) were not flagged as violations because they must be writable by design; making them point to const data would be incorrect.

- Function-pointer parameters (e.g. UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler) are not relevant to Rule 8.13, which concerns pointer-to-object const qualification.

- Calls to library functions (strcmp, malloc, memset, gethostid) are standard usages; only the surrounding pointer declarations/assignments are relevant for const qualification and have been included where potentially applicable.

If additional type definitions (e.g. the definition of StubPtr->Data.Buff.ContentTypeStr or BasePtr) are available, they should be inspected to confirm whether those fields are declared const-qualified where appropriate; the reported fragments highlight the exact sites where const qualification should be reviewed.
